pros: Best job to get AE experience without having to sell.
cons: This job does not entail value selling. This is strictly a soft auditing position. I do not foresee this Java subscription model being sustainable. Oracle monetized the Java software a couple of years ago, and the AE's job is to gain a customers trust, understand their infrastructure, hope that the customer has downloaded a "private patch" and then drop the hammer and tell them they are out of compliance. Management does a good job "holding the line"/not discounting, which almost always guarantees an angry customer, or even worse, an angry Oracle colleague who is looking to sell a legitimate product.

review_title: Great place to learn but not to grow
pros:
Good work life balance

You learn valuable tech skills even if you are not a technical person by education or trade

Starting pay is good

You get to work with fortune 100 companies daily
cons:
IC1s and IC5s basically do the same job within support so a really good IC1 or 2 can do the same amount of work as an IC5 and not earn the same income 

Large work loads can feel overbearing at times 

Upper Management is too focused on customer experience and not focused enough on employees well being 

A large amount of SMEs have left because they are not getting the pay they deserve or the ability to be involved in interesting projects

A lot of customers outsource their implementations to third party companies full of poor implementers. When the product does not work as the implementers described to the company they blame Oracle instead of the uninformed buffones who implemented it. This trend leads to long hours worth of troubleshooting issues that could have easily been avoided if the documentation was followed.

Company seems understaffed

Slow career growth

pros: Great Work Life Balance and good benefits

pros: Very good company to work
cons: No con in my experience

pros:
I love how invested the company is in their employees. Managers and senior level executives openly talk about career progression all the time. They want to help you succeed and learn new skills so you can grow. No other company I’ve worked for has been like this. It’s refreshing. All employees have access to Oracle Journeys, which has an impressive amount of material and curated paths to help you advance your career or move into a new position of interest.

My department is incredible and so are 99% of of the people I’ve met here. Everyone on the team contributes to our goals and has each other’s backs. I’ve never seen anyone ever get thrown under the bus. 

Oracle is committed to diversity and inclusion, which I love. They also donate so much money to charity, their software helps with COVID-19 vaccine production, and they do so much for the world. They’re not great about advertising it, so you may not be aware.

Oracle does genuinely value its employees. That spirit is infectious. It leads to higher morale and an environment where accomplishments are celebrated and rewarded.

Very flexible work environment.

Remote friendly for most positions.
cons:
Dealing with HR is always a nightmare. They don’t read the question or statement in your email; they see a keyword and paste semi-relevant information into the body from an internal site. Every time I’ve had to deal with them, it takes two to three emails to get a simple answer. It’s extremely frustrating.

Additionally, the timing of healthcare coverage is confusing when you join the company. Anyone you list on your insurance after you start has retroactive insurance beginning day one you started at Oracle. This means that there is no grace period to remove a spouse or child from another plan. You’d need to cancel the other plan before you technically start at Oracle or the same day. At no point did anyone make this clear to me. As a result, I paid for insurance for the same person twice until the end of the year. It’s important and worth mentioning to new hires.

Lastly, it can be difficult to initially get the tools you need to do your job. All new hires need to request their own access to all programs, sites, etc. The company is very do-it-yourself, which is fine. However, new hires need extra guidance. “Just figure it out” isn’t very welcoming when you have no idea that there are instructions on a site called Confluence. I had to figure that out on my own.

The insurance provider’s website is also misleading. It says things are 100% covered, but that can turn out not to be the case. I don’t fault Oracle because insurance companies are always awful.

review_title: Good company to work for when you don't have any option
job_title: lead client support engineer in Salt Lake City, UT
pros:
1. Unlimited sick leaves.
2. Great products and huge customer base. 
3. Opportunities to switch internally but only at same level.
4. Job security to some extent and good place for people who just take life easy and want to get paid without putting in any extra efforts.
cons:
1. People do not grow here especially in support. Seen 90% of them working at same level for 10 - 15 years and neither does management care to give them growth. Absolutely stagnant. 

2. No pay hikes whatsoever. This is in entire support organization EBS, Fusion, OCI etc. 

3. Even if you earn new qualification, still management will not consider you for any growth and neither will any team consider you at a higher level. Their thinking is if you are an IC2 or IC3 then even if you earn a harward degree we will still consider you for an IC3 only and unless you work at IC3 for 20 years we won't let you grow. It's better to leave if you are ambitious and grow elsewhere. 

4. Seen so many managers not even qualified for an engineer role but still they are managers. So, one thing proved. Here to get selected you need influence and they would even hire a joker with 0 skills to lead a team of expert engineers but would not consider a deserving engineer for a manager role. I have seen all this happening in 6 years of full time work. Those who have been working full time for years can surely relate what I am saying.

review_title: A company profile is an introduction to your business
pros:
A company profile is an introduction to your business that aims to tell an audience about your products or services.

However, a company profile shouldn't just tell your audience what you sell — it should also tell them why you sell it. It often includes a compelling story about how the company began, as well as the company's vision and values.
cons:
We all know about the infamous rivalry between Dunkin' Donuts and Starbucks. At the end of the day, they both sell coffee — but they've each cultivated strong, unique brands, and have attracted very different audiences as a result.

You can often overhear heated arguments regarding the topic, with people vehemently claiming one coffee chain to be better than the other. But let's say you didn't know about the rivalry, and you'd never heard of either Starbucks or Dunkin' Donuts before.

pros: Generous coffee break, people working in the cafe were nice.
cons: A couple of really mean people. Glad I left.

pros: Collaborative and strong strategy in the company
cons: LOB alignment meaning that there is more need for cross LOB collaboration

cons: There is not a clear path of progression in certain roles and I’m under the impression that the company expect me to leave and go somewhere else to follow my career as my specialism isn’t necessarily something that has room to grow in within my team due to the limitations of the nature of work we do.

Lack of goodwill. Years of mistreating customers from shady reps and lack of true support can be difficult to overcome.

job_title: Principal Software Engineer in Chicago, IL
pros: Great benefits - thats it.
cons:
The only way to get a raise at Oracle is to quit. You will hear this over and over from former employees - it is true. When you do ask for a raise, you will be told all of your failings, none of which even make their way into your performance reviews.

Utter lack of innovation. Considering they own Java, they are woefully behind when using it in their own products. Product lines and features are incredibly dated and behind the state of the art. OCI is a joke - a bland copy of other clouds with nothing new to offer and unlikely to be anywhere near as good.

Corporate culture at Oracle is absolutely the worst I've ever experienced. Directors try their best to create competition between teams, reducing teamwork and making for worse products. There are many processes in place to assess who is to blame, but none to reward those who deserve it,

pros:
Massive amount resources and a lot of opportunities for growth in and outside of your team.
Some teams are really fantastic to work for and there are some very high quality, supportive managers.
Work itself can be interesting and challenging and the products themselves are fantastic.
Hubs are great work locations and there is ample WFH opportunities in some organizations.
cons:
All of the resources can be hard to navigate and the over-arching culture is not very hands-on or supportive - you need to know what you're looking for in order to find it.
Some teams and managers are highly dysfunctional.
Don't count on getting a pay raise anytime soon unless you leverage an outside offer.
There's some crazy understaffing on some teams which can make the workload unmanageable.
Sales compensation is a complete mystery - you'll get some bonus/commission but have no idea why or what went into it.
Reorganizations happen at least annually, usually more frequently, which causes a lot of churn.

pros:
- If you're in a solid team with good leadership like Database, then working conditions can be good; you'll be working with people you can respect and on a proven product you can be proud of. People will denigrate the database, but let's face it -- it's the best on the market.
- Benefits are better than that of many other companies.
- Work-life balance in some teams is good, although this varies significantly
- Stability (at least at the corporate level)
- Some internal teams really have their act together and work well supporting their employees despite operating under difficult conditions. For example -- no joke -- IT.
- Some people are still willing to push forward and do their best; still a lot of solid, intelligent and nice people.
- The company's executives are experienced and competent. Larry Ellison is still deeply involved in the company's direction and has guided the company to tremendous success. 
- The company is still a leader in some areas (database (transactional)) and ERP (SaaS)
- In some cases a position here might help with further career progression elsewhere, but experience at Oracle is increasingly becoming a liability on a resume.
cons:
- You'll never get a raise or bonus
- A fairly large number of your co-workers will be deadwood or incompetent. 
- Many in the industry will view you as a loser for working there.
- Depending on where you work, conditions can be bad. Some managers are incompetent and abusive. Sales in particular is brutal.
- Let's face it; the company has failed in some critical areas; most recently spectacularly in IaaS. 
- The company's been on a downward trend for the last decade and there's no indication that will be reversed. 
- Senior management doesn't care about employees, and that uncaring attitude is pretty much the norm throughout the entire company.

pros:
- Career Development opportunities
- Lots of sales training is offered 
- You work with very well experienced colleagues who you can learn a lot from

- Not much space for creativity & corporate messaging is encouraged when reaching out to prospects

I have very big doubts a quality and consequences in one of the projects. Many things there were done to achieve very short terms goals sacrificing long term goals. From technology perspective it was very easy development (so, will not give anyone real benefits in a CV).
The culture is also broken (it can be different in other teams). Once I directly asked my team members not to share some information to management but at the end it was shared.
Management is not able to change many things that were asked by a team. Most of them came after sprint retrospectives. So, be prepared to stay alone with that.
Promotions from developers or QAs to managers looked very strange. Many team members were unsatisfied with people who was promoted and who wasn't.

review_title: Toxic environment that will stagnate your skills
job_title: Director Product Support in New York, NY
pros: Not many pros. I suppose the benefits are good. Tuition reimbursement was useful. Training opportunities are great if you want to learn Oracle tech and your management allows you to train.
cons:
Oracle is becoming irrelevant and is grasping to rise back to its heyday but they are doing this with their old tactics of browbeating employees and customers and that's not the way things work anymore. 
There is a huge internal conflict between the newer OCI teams and legacy Oracle teams that fund the growth in Cloud. This is ripping the company apart.
If you spend any serious amount of time here, it will damage your marketability on the open market. Much of the tech is not widely used and is not the latest and greatest. Managers and up do not learn how to manage and direct at a level that other companies are hiring managers (financials, project management, workforce management, etc)
There is no real career advancement - titles might change for the better but the role stays the same. There are very few chances for lateral movement and even fewer chances for management promotions - unless you know a VP.
Unless you are in OCI, there are limited raises and equity.

review_title: Subjective Review of Oracle EBS Senior Developer Role
pros:
1. You get to set up an excellent network. 
2. No Fixed Time like what you have in services companies. Work anytime you want. Managers are bothered whether you have completed the work or not, within the promised date. 
3. The work is stable, and people genuinely care to make it a good quality deliverable. There is no lack of resources, you will get all the help that you want to get the job done.
4. You will get a ton of resources, training, etc. to learn new technology. 
5. If you can set up a good rapport with the team, no need to worry about leaves.
6. Satisfactory(this is subject to debate) hike, when joining the company.
7. If you can plan, you can have a good enough work-life balance.
cons:
1. In most of the team, after a couple of months, the work will be monotonous. 
2. Very very difficult to switch to another role, or another team, even if the company says otherwise. 
3. Almost all teams are understaffed, so, there will be a huge backlog of work. 
4. Regarding financial increment, it will be very very discouraging. There will be no appreciable hikes, in the first two years. Then, whatever happens, will be way less than the average inflation. Only after spending 3/4 years, you will start seeing some hike, or stock options, that too, if you are lucky. By that time, your peers would have moved a couple of times and will be earning way more than you. The median salary in the market, for your role and experience, would have increased and you would be lagging.
5. Here the applications are built on some very stable frameworks, which rely on old/matured tech stacks, So, if you intend to grow technically, learn new things, and grow, this might not be a very good place. 
6. Even if you learn new technology, it will be extremely difficult, sometimes impossible to implement it, either as a POC in your project or as a new feature to the product, because, the applications/products rely on very old and stable frameworks.
